title: Border tree shading neighbor's field
vignette: A tall shade tree on Jordan’s property blocks sunlight from Alex’s newly planted vegetable bed, slowing the plants’ growth.

options.text: Jordan must trim or remove the tree so Alex’s crops can thrive.
The tree stays; Alex should plant farther from the fence line.

title: Four-cubits rule (first-refusal)
vignette: Casey buys an empty lot at the edge of a block.  Next-door owner Morgan insists she should have had the first chance to match the price.

options.text: Cancel the sale; Morgan may buy the lot if she pays what Casey offered.
Deal stands; once money changes hands the seller owes no neighbor preference.

title: Shared courtyard smokehouse
vignette: Two condo owners share a courtyard.  One installs a small fish-smoker; the smoky smell annoys the other residents.

options.text: Allowed—people may use the shared space for any activity common in the neighborhood.
Prohibit strong-odor uses unless every resident agrees.

title: Right of way across private land
vignette: Taylor’s land is surrounded by Riley’s larger parcel; Taylor asks for a driveway across Riley’s yard to reach the public road.

options.text: Riley must grant an access lane for a reasonable fee.
No forced passage; Taylor must purchase a full strip of land outright.

title: Movable vs. immovable boundary stakes
vignette: The property line is marked by loose stones instead of fixed posts, and the line has shifted over time.

options.text: Whoever moved it pays full damages—stones are still official markers.
Each owner bears part of the loss because such markers are easy to disturb.

title: Leaning wall between gardens
vignette: An old brick wall dividing two backyards tilts toward one side and could fall.

options.text: Both neighbors split repair costs because the wall benefits them equally.
The yard toward which it leans must pay the full repair bill.

title: Digging cistern next to neighbor's well
vignette: Jordan plans to dig a new water pit one yard from Sam’s well; Sam worries the water will drain away.

options.text: Jordan must keep a wider distance to avoid diverting water.
Jordan may dig anywhere on his own land; groundwater is common property.

title: Opening shop in residential alley
vignette: A tenant converts a ground-floor apartment into a bakery, drawing constant foot traffic; neighbors complain about noise and crowds.

options.text: Residents may veto new businesses that increase congestion.
The bakery may operate unless neighbors can prove measurable harm.

title: Upper vs. lower window privacy
vignette: Jordan adds second-story windows that face directly onto Alex’s roof deck.

options.text: High windows don’t need permission because the sight-line differs.
Alex may demand the windows be blocked to protect privacy.

title: Jointly owned scroll division
vignette: Two siblings inherit a single rare first-edition book; one proposes cutting it in half so each has a portion.

options.text: Physically split it—each gets direct ownership.
Sell the book intact and split the money; cutting destroys its value.

title: Father's gift on deathbed vs. inheritance
vignette: A father, near death, deeds his orchard to the younger child.  After he dies, the elder claims the larger legal share of the estate.

options.text: The gift deed rules; the younger keeps the orchard.
Standard inheritance applies; the elder still receives a double share.

title: Found document with blank lines
vignette: A signed sales contract contains large blank spaces that could be filled in later.

options.text: Void the contract; the blanks make it easy to forge.
Accept it if the signatures cross the margin, showing finality.

title: Boycotting unfair tax assignments
vignette: A town sets the same head-tax for every resident.  Wealthy families refuse; poorer families protest the burden.

options.text: Keep the flat tax—simplicity outweighs perfect fairness.
Tax by income tiers so the burden matches ability to pay.

title: Storefront awning over public road
vignette: A shop owner builds a low awning that hangs over the sidewalk.

options.text: City may order removal because the space above the walk is public.
Allowed if clearance is safe and similar awnings exist nearby.

title: Guardian investing orphan's funds
vignette: A trustee considers placing an orphan’s savings into a high-risk, high-return startup.

options.text: Invest only in low-risk assets to protect the principal.
High-risk is acceptable if the trustee personally guarantees any loss.

title: One writes deed, other pays scribe
vignette: Seller prepares a property deed but the buyer refuses to share the notary fee.

options.text: Buyer pays the fee because he benefits most.
Split the fee since both need a valid deed.

title: Seller keeps small profits from measurement error
vignette: Land was sold as exactly 100×100 meters; a survey shows it is slightly larger.

options.text: Buyer pays extra or returns the surplus area.
Small overage is ignored as a normal market tolerance.

title: Tunnel beneath neighbor's house
vignette: A hobby miner extends a tunnel under the edge of a neighbor’s house.

options.text: Ban the digging; it could weaken the foundation.
Permit deep tunneling that poses no realistic risk.

title: Leased house collapses midway
vignette: A renter prepaid a year’s rent; the house collapses after six months.

options.text: Landlord refunds the unused months because livable space wasn’t provided.
No refund; the collapse was an unforeseeable accident covered by the contract.

title: Sale of 'house and its contents'
vignette: A contract says “house and everything inside.”  The buyer claims loose furniture is included.

options.text: Movable items are included unless specifically excluded.
Phrase covers built-in fixtures only; furniture is separate.

title: Bird coop vs. neighbor's noise
vignette: Jordan plans to raise doves on his roof; neighbor Alex fears constant cooing will disturb sleep.

options.text: Allow the coops—country noises are normal.
Ban new coops within a set distance of bedrooms.

title: Planting thorn bushes along path
vignette: A farmer lines a private footpath with thorn bushes; passersby sometimes scratch themselves.

options.text: Owner is liable and must remove the hazard.
No liability; anyone who uses the path accepts the risk.

title: Found treasure under leased field
vignette: A tenant plows up a buried jar of coins in a rented field.

options.text: Treasure is split between tenant and landowner.
Landowner keeps it—it was buried in his soil.

title: Double deed error
vignette: A clerk mistakenly files two identical property deeds; one is recorded first.

options.text: The deed recorded first prevails; the second is void.
Both deeds are invalid; issue a single corrected document.

title: Reneging on a verbal gift
vignette: An elder promises a field to a nephew verbally, then changes his mind before signing any papers.

options.text: A verbal promise is not binding; he may retract.
He should honor the promise even without paperwork.

title: Stolen beam built into mansion
vignette: A builder discovers a load-bearing beam in his new house was stolen from a lumber yard.

options.text: The beam must be removed and returned even if the roof is torn apart.
The beam may stay if the builder pays its full value to the yard.

title: Craftsman improves raw materials
vignette: A potter hired to fire 100 clay bowls adds a special glaze that raises their resale value.

options.text: Client pays only the agreed firing fee; the glaze is a bonus.
Client must pay extra for the added value of the glaze.

title: Orphans' field sale by guardian
vignette: A guardian sells an orphan’s field to cover living expenses; years later the land’s price triples.

options.text: Sale stands because the guardian acted prudently at the time.
When grown, the orphans may cancel the sale and reclaim the land.

title: Dividing unequal-quality vineyard
vignette: Two partners split a vineyard; one half is closer to irrigation and yields better grapes.

options.text: Divide acreage 50-50; quality differences are the luck of the draw.
Adjust the split or pay cash so each partner gets equal total value.

title: Firstborn sold birthright
vignette: A firstborn son sold his extra inheritance share to a cousin while his father was alive; the father has now died.

options.text: Sale is void—extra share exists only after the father’s death.
Sale is valid; the share was a transferable future right.

title: Two dated deeds, same property
vignette: An elderly owner gifted his orchard to cousin Ava in March and, a month later, to cousin Blake.  Neither cousin has taken control.

options.text: The earlier deed to Ava prevails.
A judge may choose which cousin gets the land based on fairness.

title: Possession claim after three years
vignette: Dana has farmed Chris’s vacant lot openly for three years and now claims ownership.  Chris says he was overseas the whole time.

options.text: Dana keeps the land; three years of open use is proof of ownership.
Chris may reclaim it because he was absent and couldn’t protest.

title: Balcony overlooking courtyard
vignette: Jordan builds a balcony that looks straight into a shared courtyard where neighbors have windows.

options.text: Neighbors may demand it be removed to protect privacy.
Balcony may stay if a solid railing blocks direct view.

title: Water seepage from rooftop pool
vignette: A family sets up a kiddie pool on their roof; water leaks and stains the ceiling below.

options.text: Family is liable because the load is beyond normal weather exposure.
They pay only if damage exceeds what ordinary rain would cause.

title: Lost bond found in marketplace
vignette: A folded, unsigned loan note is found on the sidewalk; the supposed lender later claims it.

options.text: Return the note; the lender probably dropped it before signing.
Finder keeps it because the paper has no legal value or ID.

title: Right to airspace sale
vignette: A seller deeds a house “to the sky.”  Buyer wants to add a third story that will darken the neighbor’s skylight.

options.text: Buyer may build; all vertical space was conveyed.
Neighbor may block the addition because it newly harms light and air.

title: Equal division vs. lottery among heirs
vignette: Four brothers inherit four plots of unequal fertility.

options.text: Appraise the land and give each brother equal total value.
Draw lots; random selection avoids appraisal costs.

title: Guardian's advance expenses
vignette: A guardian spends his own money on seeds and tools for an orphan’s farm before court approval; the harvest is excellent.

options.text: Guardian is reimbursed plus a wage because the estate benefited.
Guardian receives only his out-of-pocket costs; he acted without consent.
